#btn_newsletter_signup.btn{ color:#ffffff; } /* Ajinkya - mw646- check if $RelatedNewsArticlesCount, $RelatedWhitepapersCount and $RelatedInterviewsCount * are set in controller. you can set it in backend by enabling checkboxes on product update form. * If not set then consider it as 0 else get actual count value in these variables. and if count is less than * 0 for any tabs content then disable that tab. */ var relatednewsarticlescount="0"; var relatedwhitepaperscount="0"; var relatedinterviewscount="0"; var reviewcount="0"; var disabledTabs = []; if(reviewcount==0) disabledTabs.push(1); if(relatednewsarticlescount==0) disabledTabs.push(2); if(relatedwhitepaperscount==0) disabledTabs.push(3); if(relatedinterviewscount==0) disabledTabs.push(4); // Ajinkya - preventCache is added since chrome tends to cache ajax requests and we don't want users to old news and //articals and other containt so curent time is passing as GET parameter to force browser to fetch data from server. var preventCache = new Date(); var page_num = 1 ; // default page number var selected_sort = '' ; // default sort type var active_tab=""; var review_id="0"; // if review_id is set directly open that review //console.log("review_id "+review_id); var live_path="https://www.hrtechnologist.com"; var author_id = '7841'; var subcategory = 'subcategory_vanity_url'; var firstAjaxCall = true; $(document).ready(function () { $('.white-panel').unwrap(); $('.white- panel').unwrap(); $('.summary').remove(); $('.yiiPager').unwrap(); var $tabs = $('#horizontalTab'); $tabs.responsiveTabs({ rotate: false, startCollapsed: 'accordion', collapsible: 'accordion', setHash: false, /** Ajinkya - setHash: false for SEO optimization , after discussion with piyush*/ disabled: disabledTabs, click: function(e, tab) { active_tab = $('a[href="'+tab.selector+'"]').attr('mtab'); if($("#"+active_tab).html()== '') { $('span.responsive-tabs- mob').html(''); $('span#'+active_tab).html(''); } else { $(".prev_namber").html(''); $('span#'+active_tab).html(''); } $('#contents_container').css('padding- right','0px'); }, activate: function(e, tab) { active_tab = $('a[href="'+tab.selector+'"]').attr('mtab'); // Ajinkya - first ajax call on document load ajaxCallOnTabChange(active_tab); }, activateState: function(e, state) { } }); firstAjaxCall = false; //to open tab in mobile view if((window.location.href.indexOf("#reviews_view") > -1) && (screen.width < 768)) { $('#reviews_tab').trigger('click'); } else { $('#new_article_tab').trigger('click'); } // if empty span hide read-more- trigger if($('.read-more-target').text().length == 0) { $('.read-more- trigger').css({"display": "none"}); } $(".read-more-target").click(function(){ var $checkbox_label = $(this).parent().siblings('.read-more-trigger'); $checkbox_label.click(); }); //initial display $("span.read-more- target").css({"display": "none"}); $('.read-more-state').change(function() { if(!$(this).is(":checked")) { $("span.read-more-target").css({"display": "none"}); $("label.read-more-trigger").html('... Show more '); }else{ $("span.read-more-target").css({"display": "inline"}); $("label.read-more-trigger").html(' Show less'); } }); }); function ajaxCallOnTabChange(active_tab) { // set default page_num and selected_sort for tab change page_num = 1; selected_sort = ''; commonAjaxCall(); } function bindAjaxForPageChange() { $(".yiiPager li a").click(function(e){ $(this).blur(); e.preventDefault(); var href = $(this).attr('href'); // set global variable page_num which will be used in commonAjaxCall() page_num = href.substr(href.indexOf("page/")+5 ,1); // where 5 for length of letters in "page/" commonAjaxCall(); }); } function bindAjaxForSortChange() { $(".sort1_right .pro_right1").change(function(){ // set global variable selected_sort which will be used in commonAjaxCall() selected_sort = $(this).val(); commonAjaxCall(); }); } function commonAjaxCall() { startLoadingImage(); beforAjaxCallSettings(); var curr_url = "https://www.hrtechnologist.com/author/authorprofiletabajax/"; //curr_url += active_tab; $.ajax({ url: curr_url, type: "GET", data: { 'sort': selected_sort, 'page_num': page_num, 'active_tab': active_tab, 'author_id':author_id, 'review_id': review_id, 'preventCache':preventCache, 'subcategory':subcategory, }, dataType: "html", success: function(data){ afterAjaxCallSettings(data); stopLoadingImage(); } }); } function afterAjaxCallSettings(data) { /* Ajinkya - Because for technical issue regarding CListview (CListview was not applying * styling for second div of class blog-landing-inner) it was difficult to display * individual content in individual divs for e.g. whitepapers in whitepapers_view div * so adjusted them in 1 sections interviews_view */ if(active_tab=="articles" ) { $("#articles_view").html(data); if (data == '') { $("#horizontalTab").hide(); } else { $("#horizontalTab").show(); $("#articles_view").html(data); } } else if( active_tab=="reviews" ) { $("#reviews_view").html(data); if (data == '') { $("#horizontalTab").hide(); } else { $("#horizontalTab").show(); $("#reviews_view").html(data); } } switch(active_tab) { case "reviews" : //bindAjaxForSortChange(); caseReviewsImage(); bindFullReviewDisplay(review_id); break; case "articles" : caseArticleWhitepaperInterviewCss(); caseArticleWhitepaperInterviewImage(); break; } resetPager(); changePagerLinks(); bindAjaxForPageChange();//since we are replacing li from ul we need to reasign the ajax event on click /* Ajinkya - Because for technical issue regarding CListview (CListview was not applying * styling for second div of class blog-landing-inner) it was difficult to display * individual content in individual divs for e.g. whitepapers in whitepapers_view div * so adjusted them in 1 sections for articles, whitepapers and interviews and another section * for product and reviews */ if(active_tab=="articles" ) { $("#articles_view").show(); } else if(active_tab=="reviews" ) { $("#reviews_view").show(); } $('.white- panel').unwrap(); $('.white-panel').unwrap(); $('.summary').remove(); } function caseReviewsImage() { $('.items .mayur').each(function(key,object) { var orig_img = $(this).find('.mayur_left a img').attr('data-original'); $(this).find('.mayur_left a img').attr('src',orig_img); }); } function caseArticleWhitepaperInterviewImage() { $('article.white- panel').each(function(key,object) { var orig_img = $(this).find('figure a img').attr('data-original'); $(this).find('figure a img').attr('src',orig_img); }); } function caseArticleWhitepaperInterviewCss() { $('#contents_container').css('padding-right','0px'); } function cleanOtherContainer(active_tab) { $( "[id$='_view']" ).each(function(){ $(this).html(''); $(this).hide(); }); } function beforAjaxCallSettings() { //Remove hash from url history.pushState("", document.title, window.location.pathname); // Scroll window to tabs link before loading next page if(!firstAjaxCall && (screen.width > 768)) { var header_ht = $(".header_top").height(); var scrollPos = $("#horizontalTab").offset().top - (header_ht+20); $(window).scrollTop(scrollPos); } $(".prev_namber").html(''); $(".sec_5top article").remove(); cleanOtherContainer(active_tab); } function getParameterByName(name,url) { name = name.replace(/[\\[]/, "\\\\[").replace(/[\\]]/, "\\\\]"); var regex = new RegExp("[\\\?&]" + name + "=([^&#]*)"), results = regex.exec(url); return results === null ? "" : decodeURIComponent(results[1].replace(/\\+/g, " ")); } function resetPager() { var pager_html = $('.pager').html(); if( typeof pager_html != "undefined" ) { $(".prev_namber").html(pager_html); } $('.pager').remove(); } function changePagerLinks() { $('.yiiPager li a').each(function(key,object) { var url=$(object).attr('href'); //console.log(url); if(active_tab=='reviews') { var page = getParameterByName('Reviews_page',url); } else { var page = getParameterByName('page',url); } var vanity_url = getParameterByName('vanity_url',url); if(page < 1) { page=1; } //console.log(vanity_url+":::"+page+":::"+url ); var new_url = live_path + "/author/authorprofiletabajax/"+"page/" + page; $(object).attr('href',''); $(object).attr('href',new_url); }); } function startLoadingImage() { $('#loader_div').show(); //console.log('ajax call started '+active_tab); } function stopLoadingImage() { $('#loader_div').hide(); //console.log('ajax call completed '+active_tab); } function bindFullReviewDisplay(review_id) { $(".read-full-list").click(function (e) { e.preventDefault(); $header = $(this); //getting the next element $content = $header.next(); $footer = $header.next().next(); $reviewitem = $header.parents('.mayur'); //open up the content needed - toggle the slide- if visible, slide up, if not slidedown. $content.slideToggle(500, function () { //execute this after slideToggle is done //change text and icon of $header based on visibility of content div if($content.is(":visible")) { $($header).html("Less "); $($footer).css('display','initial'); } else { $($header).html("More "); $($footer).css('display','none'); //Scroll to a review item using //$(window).scrollTop($($reviewitem).offset().top); } }); }); $(".read-full- list-after").click(function (e) { e.preventDefault(); $footer = $(this); //click previous anchor with class 'read-full-list'; $($footer).prev().prev().click(); }); // Ajinkya - if review_id is set then directly open full review for that review_id. if(review_id != 0) { $('.read- full-list').each(function(){ if (this.href.indexOf(review_id) != -1) { $(this).click(); } }); } } // BD added code for more link $(document).ready(function() { $("div.read-more-wrap").shorten(); }); (function($) { $.fn.shorten = function (settings) { var config = { showChars: 800, ellipsesText: "...", moreText: "Read More >>", lessText: "<< Read Less" }; if (settings) { $.extend(config, settings); } $(document).off("click", '.morelink'); $(document).on({click: function () { var $this = $(this); if ($this.hasClass('less')) { $this.removeClass('less'); $this.html(config.moreText); } else { $this.addClass('less'); $this.html(config.lessText); } $this.parent().prev().toggle(); $this.prev().toggle(); return false; } }, '.morelink'); return this.each(function () { var $this = $(this); if($this.hasClass("shortened")) return; $this.addClass("shortened"); var content = $this.html(); if (content.length > config.showChars) { var c = content.substr(0, config.showChars); var h = content.substr(config.showChars, content.length - config.showChars); var html = c + '' + config.ellipsesText + ' ' + h + ' ' + config.moreText + ''; $this.html(html); $(".morecontent span").hide(); } }); }; })(jQuery); @import # Jobs for the PEP boys as Roubler rolls out

 **[Sarah Thompson](/by/sarah-thompson-j7ger), ****[Anthony
Macdonald](/by/anthony-macdonald-j7gcx)** and **[Joyce Moullakis](/by/joyce-
moullakis-j7gdc)**

Updated Mar 1, 2017 – 11.56pm, first published at 12.15am

Save

Log in or
[Subscribe](https://subscribe.afr.com/?promote_channel=HI_AFR_GNL_HL&utm_source=afr.com&utm_medium=HouseInventory&utm_campaign=General&utm_content=HDR)
to save article

Share

Thursday looms as an exciting day for three of the biggest names in Australian
private equity, as the technology firm they have backed officially opens its
doors.

Rickard Gardell, Simon Pillar, and Tony Duthie, principals of Australia's
biggest private equity firm, Pacific Equity Partners, have personally invested
in Roubler, a human resources technology company that automates and manages
everything from tracking online job applications and ranking candidates to
rostering, monitoring time and attendance and payroll.

The business was started by Queenslander Andrew Northcott, who previously
founded labour hire group LSA Recruitment, built it into a $100 million
business (during which time it was in the BRW FAST 100 for three consecutive
years) and sold it to an international conglomerate in 2013.

![](/assets/b4682377.gif)

Roubler was started by BRW Young Rich List member Andrew Northcott (pictured),
who previously founded labour hire group LSA Recruitment ERIKA FISH

The 32-year-old has taken his time getting Roubler right, working with clients
in hospitality, construction, healthcare and transport to perfect the
platform.

Northcott says the system is smart enough to learn what sort of attributes a
candidate might offer a specific employer, and then rank prospective workers
according to their suitability.

Advertisement

It will then continue to update that information and learn more about the
employee as their career rolls on - tracking their attendance stats and time
sheets, for example, to monitor their on-going suitability for a role.

"If you look at a lot of the tech HR start ups that have come out in the last
six months they are all saying they are going to disrupt Seek and the like –
we are actually complementary to the big players," Northcott told Street Talk.

"We are not disrupting the recruitment industry as such - we are providing a
platform for and empowering internal HR teams and the recruitment industry
itself."

After the Australian launch, Roubler will target New Zealand and Singapore
before taking aim at the United States in about 18 months time.

# ASX set to open lower, RBA ahead

 **[Timothy Moore](/by/timothy-moore-h0iscf)** Online editor

Sep 3, 2019 – 4.04am

Save

Log in or
[Subscribe](https://subscribe.afr.com/?promote_channel=HI_AFR_GNL_HL&utm_source=afr.com&utm_medium=HouseInventory&utm_campaign=General&utm_content=HDR)
to save article

Share

Australian shares poised to drift lower at the open with US and Canadian
markets closed. Iron ore leapt. Base metals were mixed.

Trading was thin in Europe and trading desks were closed in the US and Canada
for a holiday. S&P 500 futures were 0.9% lower.

ASX futures were 15 points or 0.2% lower to 6537 approaching 7.30am AEST. The
S&P/ASX 200 slid 24.8 points or 0.4% on Monday.

The Australian dollar slipped 0.2%.

The local focus today is the Reserve Bank's policy decision, at 2.30pm AEST.

TD Securities said it expected the RBA to keep the cash rate at 1%. "The bank
is likely to reiterate it remains open to cutting further 'if needed'.
'Additional evidence' such as poor Q2 GDP after this last week's poor Q2
construction and building approvals data could trigger an Oct cut."

Advertisement

TD expects the RBA to cut in November and May 2020. "The risk to our forecast
is for the bank to pull the trigger earlier, not later."

RBC Capital Markets also expects no rate change today, however it too expects
a dovish tone. "While the RBA is likely to sound hopeful around early signs
that house prices may be stabilising, continued decent employment generation,
and the positive impact from fiscal and monetary stimulus, we also expect a
clear easing bias coupled with particular caution around the global outlook
and risks and the behaviour of AU households."

The spot price of iron ore, as reported by Fastmarkets MB, surged 7% to
$US90.58 a tonne.

Benchmark nickel on the London Metal Exchange ended up 0.9% at $US18,060 a
tonne, and has now gained nearly 70% this year. The stainless steel ingredient
earlier touched $US18,850 a tonne, its highest since September 2014.

Elsewhere, base metals were mixed.

Copper ended down 0.8% at $US5620 a tonne, its lowest since June 2017.
Aluminium slipped 0.2% to $US1749, but zinc gained 1.6% to $US2244, lead rose
0.2% to $US2021 and tin added 2.7% to $US16,800. Earlier, tin touched a one-
month high of $US17,575 a tonne.

The Baltic Exchange's main sea freight index rose for an eighth-straight
session on Monday, beating a near nine-year peak marked at the end of last
week and helped by robust capesize demand.

The Baltic index, which tracks rates for ships ferrying dry bulk commodities,
gained 64 points, or 2.7%, to 2442, a level last seen in November 2010.

Advertisement

## Today's agenda

Local: Balance of payments second quarter, Retail sales July, RBA policy
decision at 2.30pm

Overseas data: Euro zone PPI July; US Markit manufacturing PMI August, ISM
manufacturing August, Construction spending July

## Market highlights

ASX futures down 15 points or 0.2% lower to 6537 approaching 7.30am AEST

  * AUD -0.2% to 67.17 US cents
  * US, Canadian markets closed for Labor Day holiday
  * Dow Jones futures -0.9%, S&P 500 futures -0.9%, Nasdaq futures -1%
  * In Europe: Stoxx 50 +0.2% FTSE +1% CAC +0.2% DAX +0.1%
  * Nikkei 225 futures -0.2%
  * Spot gold +0.6% to $US1529.30 an ounce near 1.30pm New York time
  * Brent crude -1% to $US58.64 a barrel
  * US oil -0.6% to $US54.77 a barrel
  * Iron ore +7% to $US90.58 a tonne
  * Dalian iron ore +3.4% to 639 yuan
  * LME aluminium -0.2% to $US1749 a tonne
  * LME copper -0.8% to $US5620 a tonne
  * 2-year yield: US 1.50% Australia 0.73%
  * 5-year yield: US 1.39% Australia 0.69%
  * 10-year yield: US 1.50%Australia 0.92% Germany -0.71%
  * 10-year US/Australia yield gap near 3.30am AEST: 58 basis points

## From today's Financial Review

[Economy will pick-up after 'soft' June
quarter](https://www.afr.com/politics/federal/josh-frydenberg-economy-will-
pick-up-after-soft-gdp-june-quarter-20190902-p52mz6): Ignore what will be a
poor growth number for the June quarter and focus on September, Treasurer Josh
Frydenberg urges.

Advertisement

[High valuations firm as the new normal for tech
stocks](https://www.afr.com/technology/high-valuations-firm-as-the-new-normal-
for-tech-stocks-20190830-p52mcl): Australia's star tech stocks have kept
investors dreaming in reporting season, with WiseTech, Altium and Afterpay
enjoying strong post-results price growth.

[Ewen Crouch puts reputation on the line to back Corporate
Travel](https://www.afr.com/chanticleer/crouch-puts-reputation-on-the-
line-20190902-p52n4t): Westpac director Ewen Crouch is taking on the short
sellers with his chairmanship of Corporate Travel Management. He is a believer
in the business and its CEO Jamie Pherous, who has built a $2 billion company
over 25 years.

## United States

RBC on pending US data: "Payrolls are due on Friday and nothing in the high-
frequency employment data suggests that a deceleration in job growth is in the
offing: (1) initial jobless claims remain at the all-time lows when adjusted
for the labour force, highlighting limited stress in the space; (2) the
insured unemployment rate (the u-rate for those covered by unemployment
insurance) remains at the all-time low of just 1.2%; (3) confidence in the
labour backdrop also just hit a fresh cycle high with the so-called labour
differential (the share of consumers saying jobs are “plentiful” minus those
saying they are “hard to get”) jumping to 39.4 in August from 33.1 in July and
28.2 in June; (4) the labour market remains tight, with openings still
outnumbering hiring by about 1.6 million (an unprecedented phenomenon); (5)
the share of small firms with few or no qualified applicants for job openings
rose to an all-time high in July—an eye-popping 56%.

 **"** So if job growth is indeed going to slow, it will not be because of
waning economic growth but rather an inability to find workers **.** This
dynamic typically leads to firming wages, which are an important offset to
slowing job growth. With all of this in mind, we look for August headline and
private payrolls to print near their longer-run trend of about 180/175k,
respectively. The u-rate should remain under pressure and we anticipate that
it will slide to 3.6% from 3.7%."

## Europe

[British PM turns the screw on rebel Tory MPs ahead of key
vote](https://www.afr.com/world/europe/british-pm-turns-the-screw-on-rebel-
tory-mps-ahead-of-key-vote-20190903-p52nab): Boris Johnson warns they are
stymeing his talks with Brussels, and has threatened to call an immediate
election.

European stocks closed higher in thin trading on Monday, with investors
favouring defensive sectors as the United States and China imposed more
tariffs, while a slide in the pound helped Britain's FTSE 100 outperform.

Advertisement

The pan-European STOXX 600 closed up 0.3%, starting September on a positive
note after global trade disputes and recession worries drove the benchmark
down 1.6% in August.

After a tumultuous month, equity investors largely shrugged off the latest
escalation in the trade spat as Washington began imposing 15% tariffs on a
variety of Chinese goods on Sunday and Beijing reciprocated with new duties on
US crude oil.

London shares jumped 1%, outpacing their European peers, as the
internationally focused stocks got a boost from a a slump in sterling on fresh
Brexit worries.

On the main STOXX index, defensive sectors such as food and beverage,
healthcare and utilities - which tend to be favoured during times of economic
uncertainty - led the gainers.

In the latest evidence of trade war taking a toll on global growth, a series
of business surveys from China to Europe showed factory activity was largely
in decline in August.

An ongoing decline in export-reliant Germany meant factory activity in the
euro zone contracted for a seventh month in August, bolstering expectations
the European Central Bank will ease monetary policy next week.

"The data hasn't changed views much. You're left with the fact that a lot of
negatives about the trade war has been discounted in the recent days,"
Rabobank's Philip Marey said.

## Asia

Advertisement

A credit-fuelled stimulus splurge could hurt China's credit rating more than
the immediate hit from US trade tariffs, S&P Global's main analyst for the
country says.

S&P last cut China's rating a couple of years ago, but it has been almost a
year since its last formal review of the world's number two economy and a lot
has happened since.

A full-blown trade war has developed with the United States and caused the
sharpest slowdown in China's economic growth in decades.

Beijing has been trying to offset the damage with various forms of stimulus,
but S&P's primary sovereign analyst for China, Kim Eng, said there was a risk
it ends up going too far with the efforts.

"If we have an abrupt shock of some sort then I think the government might
start running for the more immediate kinds of economic support," Eng said.

"That in our view will mean the banks will have to start lending quite quickly
and that would be negative for the government's rating."

S&P currently rates China at A+ with a stable outlook. That is the same as
both Moody's and Fitch. But it can often be the first of the three main
agencies to move which means its imminent review will be closely watched.

TD on the latest China data: "The details of the official manufacturing PMI
were unconstructive, with headline diverging from a potential recovery path,
to tick down 0.2p to 49.5 (slightly worse than expected). The same pattern was
evident in new orders, purchases, input price and output price sub-indices.
While new export orders did tick up 0.3p to 47.2, imports collapsed 0.7p to a
post-Q1 (when stimulus temporarily bolstered the PMI) low.

Advertisement

"By industrial size, large-scale enterprises which have bolstered the PMI of
late fell back to 50.1, while the average of the small and medium-sized
enterprises are ticking back to the post Q1 lows, and both well
contractionary.

"The official services PMI ticked higher by 0.1 to 53.8, but underlying
details continue to weaken."

## Currencies

[RBA QE is a currency war tool](https://www.afr.com/policy/economy/rba-qe-is-
a-currency-war-tool-20190828-p52lpy): It is clear from recent remarks by
governor Philip Lowe and deputy Guy Debelle that the RBA would contemplate QE
if other central banks aggressively cut rates towards zero and the local
economy faced a sharp downturn from the US-China trade war.

Argentine bond prices fell to record lows on Monday and a jittery peso see-
sawed between losses and gains after the country imposed capital controls on
Sunday in a bid to stem a currency rout that is sharpening the risk of
default.

The move by President Mauricio Macri, a free-markets advocate who abolished
capital controls after he came to power in 2015, is a sharp about-face for his
administration after the conservative leader was pummelled in primary
elections in August.

Since then, the country's peso, bonds and equities have tumbled, forcing Macri
to unveil plans to delay payments on around $US100 billion of debts as well as
the currency controls restricting the purchase of dollars.

The peso edged up 0.88% in official markets, but fell in the black market
1.56% to 64 per dollar, a divergence underscoring a loss of trust in the
official price that was also helped by a market holiday in the United States.

Advertisement

"The dollar at this level is now strong enough," Treasury Minister Hernan
Lacunza told a news conference. "All these measures have the central objective
of stability."

The official peso had lost more than 23% since the August 11 primary election
turned the country's politics on its head, with incumbent Macri getting
soundly thrashed by his populist-leaning opponent Alberto Fernandez.

The currency is down more than a third so far this year, following a more than
50% drop last year. The central bank has burned through nearly $US1 billion in
reserves since Wednesday, but has failed to stem the peso's slide.

## Commodities

Nickel prices hit five-year highs on Monday due to worries about shortages as
top producer Indonesia said it would stop ore exports from January 2020, two
years earlier than initially flagged.

Benchmark nickel on the London Metal Exchange ended up 0.9% at $US18,060 a
tonne, and has now gained nearly 70% this year. The stainless steel ingredient
earlier touched $US18,850 a tonne, its highest since September 2014.

"It's a time-lag problem rather than a supply problem, although we will have a
supply problem in the future with demand growth from the battery sector," said
Caspar Rawles, analyst at Benchmark Mineral Intelligence.

Nickel is a major component of the lithium-ion rechargeable batteries used in
electric vehicles, sales of which are expected to rise sharply as governments
and consumers look to cut noxious fumes from fossil-fuelled cars.

Advertisement

"We've had a long period of low prices. Higher prices are needed to
incentivise new production," Rawles said. "Higher prices are a good thing for
the supply chain, particularly as the world moves towards electric cars."

## Australian sharemarket

[Value investors to ride yield curve doom](https://www.afr.com/markets/equity-
markets/value-investors-to-ride-yield-curve-doom-20190902-p52n4d): Value
investing has lagged over the past decade, but in a world of inverted yield
curves the strategy may deliver diversification and potential outperformance.

Earnings revisions and a number of ex-dividends hit several stocks on Monday,
pushing the local sharemarket lower for the first session of the month.

A lack of reaction to[ the implementation of tariffs on $US100 billion worth
of Chinese goods](https://www.afr.com/link/follow-20180501-p52mm5) announced
earlier this year saw the market open the session just slightly weaker before
sliding throughout the session as Wall Street futures opened lower.

The S&P/ASX 200 Index closed 24.8 points, or 0.4 per cent, lower at 6579.4
with trading volumes well below normal.
